text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

I think the most powerful and
exciting feature of the case

method is also its
principal challenge, which

is that, on most
days, students have

just as much influence over
the course of the discussion
as professors do.

And when you get 93
brains looking at a case

and looking for new angles,
you are virtually guaranteed

to emerge with
something new, something

that you'd never considered
before or explored
in any depth.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

It's a very respectful
way of learning.

It requires a lot of
trust in students,

a lot of trust in the professor
to get to the broader learning
that we want to achieve.

Natalia and I are
development economists.

We study how to empower small
businesses in the developing
world.

I think Hush Power is a great
demonstration of the magic
of the case method.

They provide clean energy
to rural households

and small businesses in India
and in parts of east Africa.

It is an organization
that is thinking

about how to help
entrepreneurs overcome

the challenges that they
face in a poor country

and, at the same time,
thinking about how

to do that
sustainably, by earning

enough money to actually
make it in the long run.

Our plan had been to
discuss the business models.

And at some point, some
student raised her hand

and decided that she
would refocus discussion
on Husk's investors.

Her question was, who
are these people who

were willing to take a bet on
the earliest versions of Husk's

business model
when it was clearly
an unprofitable business model?

That discussion was
hugely formative

not only for how we
now teach the case

but also for the kinds of
work, research case writing,
that Natalia and I do today.

It really spurred a
new research agenda

for myself and for Ben in
which we think about impact
investors in the United States.
And what exactly are they doing?

Why are they making
those decisions?

And are they having
the kind of impact

that they hope to be
having, and is that

the most efficient way for
us to have a social impact
as a business community?

We really became
quite interested

in the kinds of
investors who place

social impact, environmental
impact on the same level,

on the same plane as
their financial returns.

And I think that's what
led Natalia to really focus
on Collab Capital.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

So Collab is a exciting
new venture capital firm.

So it was started by
three Black entrepreneurs,

and they kind of
have a dual goal.

First, they want to make
as much money as they can.

And secondly, they
want to do that

by exploiting an opportunity
that they believe

has been unexploited
in the market

so far in venture capital,
which is to invest
in Black entrepreneurs.

And in that way, they have
both a financial mission but,

at the same time, to have the
social impact in which they

can make communities
of color wealthier.

And this is one of the
most concrete opportunities
that students have to evaluate.
Hey.

This new firm, this is one
of their main missions,

is to empower Black
entrepreneurs.

Are they doing it
in a way that we

think is going to be
sustainable, that it's
going to have a big impact?

And if the answer is maybe,
what other ways could

we think of here
in this classroom

to fix venture capital
given that we really

care about making sure that
venture capital is inclusive?

They're really at the frontier
of the kinds of questions

that they are facing,
both in the business world

but also from a
social perspective.

The students here are
so hungry for learning

about the kinds of
businesses that make
a positive impact on the world.

And if, at the end
of the day, you

feel that you've raised
more questions than answers,

it's very likely that
you've built a great case.

That kind of
intellectual freedom

allows you to explore
just a huge range
of important questions.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
